summary: Choriocarcinoma is a trophoblastic cancer that usually originates in the placenta. It is characterized by early hematogenous spread to the lungs and is considered the malignant end of gestational trophoblastic disease (GTD). It can also arise in the testis or ovary as a germ cell tumor.
causes: Trophoblastic components in mixed germ cell tumors
diagnosis: Identification of syncytiotrophoblasts and cytotrophoblasts without placental villi
Elevated blood levels of beta-human chorionic gonadotropin (beta-HCG)
treatments: Chemotherapy (single-agent methotrexate or actinomycin-D for low-risk disease)
Combination chemotherapy regimens (EMACO: etoposide, methotrexate, actinomycin D, cyclophosphamide, vincristine for intermediate or high-risk disease)
Hysterectomy (for patients >40 years or those for whom sterilization is not an obstacle, or with severe infection and uncontrolled bleeding)
Chemotherapy (less effective for testicular or ovarian choriocarcinoma)
